awd_titl_txt: RUI: A Search For Dark Matter With Superheated Liquid Targets
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the most enduring mysteries in science is the explanation for the evidence that, on all scales larger than a single star, far more gravitating material is seen to exist than can be accounted for by the atoms in these systems. This material, called Dark Matter (DM), is intrinsically invisible and has only conclusively been seen by its gravitational effects in aggregate. The objective of this project is to test the hypothesis that DM is an exotic particle, constituting about 85% of the mass of the Universe. If DM is observed in this detector, the project would be able to characterize basic properties such as its mass and the strength with which it interacts with ordinary matter.

Many undergraduates have participated in the work at IUSB as have high school teachers and students. They have participated in all aspects of "big science" at an undergraduate institution. The group has aided the broader scientific community by fabricating specially designed transducers for a wide array of operating environments. An astrophysics experiment is now using acoustic particle ID in a bubble chamber to study exotic reactions relevant to large stars. The Muon Ionization Cooling Experiment uses them to understand electrical breakdown in RF cavities. A competing dark matter experiment uses them to eliminate boiling background. A neutron parity violation spin rotation experiment will use them to understand bubble migration in liquid helium.

This award provides funds to enable the IUSB group to continue to contribute to the detector R&D, installation, commissioning and running of the PICO bubble chambers and analysis of the resulting data. PICO uses superheated liquids to search for the tiny energy depositions left by nuclei recoiling due to collisions with dark matter. These depositions cause the liquid to explosively transform into gas. The bubble chamber technique represents a unique approach in the field, since it is inherently immune to sparsely ionizing particles (such as electrons), which are serious backgrounds to other DM detectors. This will be especially important if robust observation claims are made by experiments in the future. It has also been demonstrated by the group that the target fluids are easily changed, which will be important in determining the properties of any observed DM particle. The IUSB group has designed and fabricated all of the acoustic transducers for the detectors. The group recently discovered that one can even distinguish what kind of nucleus has decayed. IUSB also participates in the commissioning and running of the various bubble chambers at the deep site and energy threshold experiments at the Fermilab test-beam facility. A new design for transducers mounted in the dome over the bellows system will be made for a ton-scale detector. The group will also continue to contribute to the analysis of data already collected with the COUPP-60 and PICO-2L detectors.

por.por_cntn:
This grant allowed Indiana University South Bend to contribute to the direct search for dark matter for two years, proving that we had overcome a potential stumbling block for larger scale detectors and developing new detector component designs relevant to a larger scale detector. The PICO experiment continues to be the most sensitive technique to search for a dark matter candidate that interacts dominantly with the proton spin of ordinary nuclei - a candidate which arises naturally in some of the most plausible scenarios already envisioned by theorists, but also more general scenarios.

The PICO bubble chamber experiment had recently encountered a troubling source of background which prevented the collaboration from building a ton-scale detector, which is the next natural size of detector to field. This grant helped IUSB do its part to field a new version of the PICO-60 detector meant to demonstrate that this background had been overcome. It also allowed the IUSB group to work on changes to the design of acoustic transducers which are IUSB’s main responsibility.  These sensors are used for distinguishing, on an event-by-event basis, signals in the chamber from radioactive decay from those caused by dark matter interactions – should they occur in our detectors.  

The group invented the technique of identifying the nature of subatomic particles, based upon the differences in sound that they make in the detector. Therefore, these sound sensors are essential components of the bubble chamber when trying to study rare events such as dark matter scattering off of nuclei. 

In parallel, the group pursued modifications to the design of the transducers that could function inside a ton scale detector which will have quite different operating conditions from all of PICO’s previous chambers. The two biggest differences are that future chambers will run at temperatures of about -25C (in the portion of the detector where the transducers reside-previously, ambient temperatures were +40C) and the hydraulic fluid they are immersed in is being changed from propylene glycol to mineral oil. The IUSB group had to ensure chemical and mechanical durability of all detector components with immersion in mineral oil, which normally sits at atmospheric pressure, but is periodically raised to pressures of about 10 atmospheres in about 0.04 seconds.  We also had to test that there are no problems with durability or function of the transducers at the cold temperatures.

During this time, the IUSB group helped demonstrate that the background problem had indeed been resolved, that the acoustic sensor will function as desired in the large scale detector, that they should be more mechanically and electrically robust than previous versions and that a new method of fielding them will not impair their performance, but will result in less radioactive background being introduced in the chamber. We are now finalizing construction of a 40kg demonstration model of the new design of cold detector along with an assortment of transducers to prove their performance in-situ, prior to building the ton-scale detector.

While these activities were being pursued, the IUSB team helped the collaboration do the most stringent tests in the world for one leading class of dark matter particle candidates. These results were published in the research journals Physical Review Letters, Physical Review D (2 publications) and Astroparticle Physics.

During the two year time-frame of this grant, the IUSB group has trained 2 high school students (one of whom plans to attend IUSB as a physics major), 1 high school science teacher who continues to collaborate with the group and 12 undergraduate students in research techniques, data analysis using MATLAB software, machining skills (lathes, mills, drill presses, various saws, etc.), electronics training, report-writing, oral presentations and safety in the work place. Of the six students who graduated two have entered graduate school in aeronautical engineering, one has become an accelerator technician, another is a participant in a software startup, one has entered graduate school in chemistry and one has become a sailor. The other students are still in school at various stages of completion of their degrees and still involved with research projects in the group.
